elements.content: Synthesis of porous carbons on direct carbonization of nonporous Zn-based MOFs has been achieved without using any additional carbon precursor. The effect of ligand nature on the resulting carbon porosity has been studied systematically using the MOFs synthesized from rigid and flexible ligands. The linear relations between Zn/C ratio of the MOF versus surface area of the resulting carbon, microporosity versus H2 uptake achieved in these carbons, and surface area versus specific capacitance of the end carbons have been verified from the gas adsorption, molecular composition, and electrochemical studies, respectively. Cyclic voltammetry and charge–discharge cycling have been carried out to study the capacitive behavior of the carbons. The interdependence of capacitive behavior on the surface area has been analyzed using data derived from N2 adsorption isotherms and charge–discharge curves. Among the carbons synthesized, C-MOF-2 shows maximal surface area of 1378 m2/g with a specific capacitance of 170 F/g at 1 A/g.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of porous carbons on direct carbonization of nonporous Zn-based MOFs has been achieved without using any additional carbon precursor. The effect of ligand nature on the resulting carbon porosity has been studied systematically using the MOFs synthesized from rigid and flexible ligands. The linear relations between Zn/C ratio of the MOF versus surface area of the resulting carbon, microporosity versus H2 uptake achieved in these carbons, and surface area versus specific capacitance of the end carbons have been verified from the gas adsorption, molecular composition, and electrochemical studies, respectively. Cyclic voltammetry and charge-discharge cycling have been carried out to study the capacitive behavior of the carbons. The interdependence of capacitive behavior on the surface area has been analyzed using data derived from N2 adsorption isotherms and charge-discharge curves. Among the carbons synthesized, C-MOF-2 shows maximal surface area of 1378 m2/g with a specific capacitance of 170 F/g at 1 A/g.

elements.content: Synthesis of porous carbons from nonporous MOFs has been studied. The obtained carbons with moderate porosity show H2 and CO2 uptake as well as porosity-dependent capacitance. The effect of ligand flexibility on the resulting carbon porosity has been studied systematically.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of porous carbons from nonporous MOFs has been studied. The obtained carbons with moderate porosity show H2 and CO2 uptake as well as porosity-dependent capacitance. The effect of ligand flexibility on the resulting carbon porosity has been studied systematically.

elements.content: Porous carbons are favorably placed as efficient materials for a wide spectrum of industrial applications, owing to their tailorable surface area and porosity. Recent carbon research focuses on the template-based synthesis of carbonaceous materials for a better control on their physical and chemical properties in addition to the desired morphology. An ideal starting material is the one that can act as both template and carbon precursor. In that direction, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) serve as excellent candidates in deriving the carbon nanostructures due to their tunable yet high porosity, higher stability, and low framework density. Thus, synthesis of porous carbon from porous MOFs via direct carbonization has been recently used as an easy approach to obtain nanostructured carbons. However, in most of such cases, the selected MOFs with intrinsic porosity are observed to result in carbons with lower surface area in comparison to that of their parent. There exists only one report of synthesis of porous carbons with very high surface area via carbonization of nonporous MOFs. These results challenge the concept that only porous MOFS are required to produce porous carbons. Hitherto, a common logic to explain this phenomenon is still not established, and the concept of conversion of nonporous MOFs to porous carbons has been hardly worked on.
elements.clean_text: Porous carbons are favorably placed as efficient materials for a wide spectrum of industrial applications, owing to their tailorable surface area and porosity. Recent carbon research focuses on the template-based synthesis of carbonaceous materials for a better control on their physical and chemical properties in addition to the desired morphology. An ideal starting material is the one that can act as both template and carbon precursor. In that direction, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) serve as excellent candidates in deriving the carbon nanostructures due to their tunable yet high porosity, higher stability, and low framework density. Thus, synthesis of porous carbon from porous MOFs via direct carbonization has been recently used as an easy approach to obtain nanostructured carbons. However, in most of such cases, the selected MOFs with intrinsic porosity are observed to result in carbons with lower surface area in comparison to that of their parent. There exists only one report of synthesis of porous carbons with very high surface area via carbonization of nonporous MOFs. These results challenge the concept that only porous MOFS are required to produce porous carbons. Hitherto, a common logic to explain this phenomenon is still not established, and the concept of conversion of nonporous MOFs to porous carbons has been hardly worked on.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis of porous carbons from Zn-based nonporous MOFs, viz. C-MOF-5 (MOF-5), C-MOF-2 (MOF-2), C–Zn–BTC (Zn-1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid), C–Zn–NDC (Zn-2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid), C–Zn–PAA (Zn-1,4-phenylenediacetic acid), and C–Zn–ADA (Zn-1,3-adamantanediacetic acid) and demonstrate their application as potential energy devices. We have additionally studied the effect of ligand characteristics on the resulting carbon by varying different organic linkers containing rigid aromatic to flexible alicyclic backbones in these MOFs. Porosity and H2 as well as CO2 uptake of the resulting carbons were evaluated. Electrochemical studies were carried out to evaluate their potential as electrodic materials for electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs). These Zn-based MOFs, namely MOF-5 [Zn4O(BDC)3], MOF-2 [(H2NEt2)2[Zn3(BDC)4]·3DEF], Zn–BTC [Zn3(BTC)2(DMSO)4], Zn–NDC [Zn(NDC)(H2O)], and Zn-PAA [Zn2(PAA)2], were synthesized and subsequently characterized by PXRD. The synthesis of nonporous 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid-based MOF, Zn–ADA, was performed through the solvothermal synthetic route. In the typical procedure following, equal volumes of 0.1 mmol of ZnClO4. 6 H2O, and 1,3-adamantane diacetic acid each were taken in DMF:CH3OH (2:1) solvent mixture and stirred at room temperature for 15 min followed by heating at 90 °C for 3 days. Colorless, flowerlike crystals were obtained, and the structure was confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S7 and Table S1 of the ). The phase purity and crystallinity of the bulk Zn-ADA was further confirmed by PXRD (Figure S9 of the ). These as-synthesized Zn-based MOFs were carbonized at 1000 °C for 3 h at a ramp of 5 °C/min under extra pure (99.99%) argon flow. The temperature was chosen to be 1000 °C in order to facilitate the carbonization of the MOFs along with the simultaneous reduction of the ZnO species formed to metallic zinc by carbon during the process (900 °C being the boiling point of Zn metal). Broad peaks appearing at 2θ values of ∼26 and ∼44° correspond to the respective diffractions from the (002) and (100) planes of the carbon (Figure S9a of the ). These peaks indicate the presence of long-range two-dimensional ordering in the carbon matrix along with some degree of graphitization. The absence of ZnO peaks confirmed the purity of the resulting nanoporous carbons. In addition, the ICP and EDAX analysis were carried out, which further validated the absence of traceable ZnO impurities in the system (Figure S10 of the ). The Raman spectra of all the carbons show two characteristic peaks centered around ∼1330 cm–1 (the disordered, or D band) and ∼1580 cm–1 (the graphitic, or G band), respectively (Figure S9b of the ), which suggests the presence of sp2 sites in the resultant carbons. SEM analyses reveal the retention of the original MOF crystal morphology in all these MOF-derived carbons except for C–Zn–ADA (Figure and Figure S11 of the ).
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis of porous carbons from Zn-based nonporous MOFs, viz. C-MOF-5 (MOF-5), C-MOF-2 (MOF-2), C-Zn-BTC (Zn-1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid), C-Zn-NDC (Zn-2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid), C-Zn-PAA (Zn-1,4-phenylenediacetic acid), and C-Zn-ADA (Zn-1,3-adamantanediacetic acid) and demonstrate their application as potential energy devices. We have additionally studied the effect of ligand characteristics on the resulting carbon by varying different organic linkers containing rigid aromatic to flexible alicyclic backbones in these MOFs. Porosity and H2 as well as CO2 uptake of the resulting carbons were evaluated. Electrochemical studies were carried out to evaluate their potential as electrodic materials for electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs). These Zn-based MOFs, namely MOF-5 [Zn4O(BDC)3], MOF-2 [(H2NEt2)2[Zn3(BDC)4]⋅3DEF], Zn-BTC [Zn3(BTC)2(DMSO)4], Zn-NDC [Zn(NDC)(H2O)], and Zn-PAA [Zn2(PAA)2], were synthesized and subsequently characterized by PXRD. The synthesis of nonporous 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid-based MOF, Zn-ADA, was performed through the solvothermal synthetic route. In the typical procedure following, equal volumes of 0.1 mmol of ZnClO4. 6 H2O, and 1,3-adamantane diacetic acid each were taken in DMF:CH3OH (2:1) solvent mixture and stirred at room temperature for 15 min followed by heating at 90 °C for 3 days. Colorless, flowerlike crystals were obtained, and the structure was confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S7 and Table S1 of the ). The phase purity and crystallinity of the bulk Zn-ADA was further confirmed by PXRD (Figure S9 of the ). These as-synthesized Zn-based MOFs were carbonized at 1000 °C for 3 h at a ramp of 5 °C/min under extra pure (99.99%) argon flow. The temperature was chosen to be 1000 °C in order to facilitate the carbonization of the MOFs along with the simultaneous reduction of the ZnO species formed to metallic zinc by carbon during the process (900 °C being the boiling point of Zn metal). Broad peaks appearing at 2θ values of ~26 and ~44° correspond to the respective diffractions from the (002) and (100) planes of the carbon (Figure S9a of the ). These peaks indicate the presence of long-range two-dimensional ordering in the carbon matrix along with some degree of graphitization. The absence of ZnO peaks confirmed the purity of the resulting nanoporous carbons. In addition, the ICP and EDAX analysis were carried out, which further validated the absence of traceable ZnO impurities in the system (Figure S10 of the ). The Raman spectra of all the carbons show two characteristic peaks centered around ~1330 cm-1 (the disordered, or D band) and ~1580 cm-1 (the graphitic, or G band), respectively (Figure S9b of the ), which suggests the presence of sp2 sites in the resultant carbons. SEM analyses reveal the retention of the original MOF crystal morphology in all these MOF-derived carbons except for C-Zn-ADA (Figure  and Figure S11 of the ).

Schematic Representation for the Synthesis of Porous Carbon on Direct Carbonization of (a) Porous MOF and (b) Nonporous MOFs at 1000 °C Along with their N<sub>2</sub> Adsorption Isotherms<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The structures of the nonporous MOFs, MOF-2, Zn–NDC, Zn–BTC, and Zn–PAA are shown inside the green frame. Solvent molecules present in the MOF structures are omitted for clarity. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, grey.

Solvent molecules present in the MOF structures are omitted for clarity. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, grey.

elements.content: Secondary Binding Units (SBUs) of MOFs and corresponding SEM and TEM images of porous carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs at 1000 °C. The ranking of the constituting rigid/flexible ligands is made based on the number of sp2/sp3 carbons present in their backbone.
elements.clean_text: 1  Secondary Binding Units (SBUs) of MOFs and corresponding SEM and TEM images of porous carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs at 1000 °C. The ranking of the constituting rigid/flexible ligands is made based on the number of sp2/sp3 carbons present in their backbone.

elements.content: In order to further substantiate the effect of MOF porosity as well as ligand flexibility on the resulting end carbon morphology, we performed TEM analyses of all the carbons. The high-resolution TEM images of the carbons clearly indicate the presence of well-ordered and periodic arrangement of carbon sheets with prominent and larger-sized pores ranging from 5–10 nm in the carbon matrix of C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC (Figure and Figure S11 of the ). In contrast, C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA have a less-ordered, sheetlike arrangement in the carbon matrix with smaller pores (2–7 nm). The MOFs containing aromatic linkers are found to show a good degree of rigidity and seem to maintain the original MOF morphology, even after carbonization at higher temperature (Figure ). Conversely, this does not seem to be the same in the case of C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA, wherein a two-dimensional (2D) sheet phase can be observed in the carbon matrix in the SEM analyses. From the TEM imaging of carbons, it is clear that the structural arrangement or rigidity of MOF architecture is a responsible factor for the formation of ordered pores in the carbon matrix. In general it is believed that, during MOF decomposition, the structure breaks down, thereby restricting its use as a true hard template for carbon formation. However, as evident from SEM as well as TEM images, one could still observe the presence of pores along with the retention of original MOF morphology with few exceptions, which substantiates the role of these MOFs as ideal templates for carbonization (Figure S11 of the ).
elements.clean_text: In order to further substantiate the effect of MOF porosity as well as ligand flexibility on the resulting end carbon morphology, we performed TEM analyses of all the carbons. The high-resolution TEM images of the carbons clearly indicate the presence of well-ordered and periodic arrangement of carbon sheets with prominent and larger-sized pores ranging from 5-10 nm in the carbon matrix of C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C-Zn-NDC, and C-Zn-BTC (Figure  and Figure S11 of the ). In contrast, C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA have a less-ordered, sheetlike arrangement in the carbon matrix with smaller pores (2-7 nm). The MOFs containing aromatic linkers are found to show a good degree of rigidity and seem to maintain the original MOF morphology, even after carbonization at higher temperature (Figure ). Conversely, this does not seem to be the same in the case of C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA, wherein a two-dimensional (2D) sheet phase can be observed in the carbon matrix in the SEM analyses. From the TEM imaging of carbons, it is clear that the structural arrangement or rigidity of MOF architecture is a responsible factor for the formation of ordered pores in the carbon matrix. In general it is believed that, during MOF decomposition, the structure breaks down, thereby restricting its use as a true hard template for carbon formation. However, as evident from SEM as well as TEM images, one could still observe the presence of pores along with the retention of original MOF morphology with few exceptions, which substantiates the role of these MOFs as ideal templates for carbonization (Figure S11 of the ).

elements.content: The N2 adsorption analyses of the activated samples of MOFs indicate that except MOF-5 [Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, 2385 m2/g], all other MOFs have poor/no porosity with surface area between 20–65 m2/g (Figure S8 of the ). The gas adsorption analyses of MOF-derived carbons show typical Type-I N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms without any hysteresis, which suggests a dominating microporous nature in the carbon matrix (Figure ). The BET surface areas calculated between a pressure range of 0.1–0.3 atm for carbons derived from MOFs having rigid aromatic linkers [i.e., C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–BTC, and C–Zn–NDC are 2184, 1378, 1326, and 920 m2/g respectively (Figure a)]. However, the BET surface areas of carbons synthesized from the MOFs with flexible linkers [i.e., C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn-ADA are 495 and 513 m2/g, respectively (Figure b and Table S3 of the )]. This is in good agreement with the previously reported phenomenon. However, we could additionally observe that the linear relation between the Zn/C ratio and surface area is valid only in the case of MOFs with rigid ligands [i.e., benzene derivatives like 1,4-BDC, 1,3,5-BTC, and 2,6-NDC, whereas the MOFs containing flexible ligands like 1,3-ADA and 1,4-PAA result in low surface area carbons and henceforth fail to fall in the linear plot (Figure e)]. This may be due to the close resemblance in the property of alicyclic linkers of MOFs, particularly the adamantane-based ligand with the pitchlike compounds, which hints at the existence of a mesophase intermediate state prior to the solid “soft” carbon formation.
elements.clean_text: The N2 adsorption analyses of the activated samples of MOFs indicate that except MOF-5 [Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, 2385 m2/g], all other MOFs have poor/no porosity with surface area between 20-65 m2/g (Figure S8 of the ). The gas adsorption analyses of MOF-derived carbons show typical Type-I N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms without any hysteresis, which suggests a dominating microporous nature in the carbon matrix (Figure ). The BET surface areas calculated between a pressure range of 0.1-0.3 atm for carbons derived from MOFs having rigid aromatic linkers [i.e., C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C-Zn-BTC, and C-Zn-NDC are 2184, 1378, 1326, and 920 m2/g respectively (Figure a)]. However, the BET surface areas of carbons synthesized from the MOFs with flexible linkers [i.e., C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA are 495 and 513 m2/g, respectively (Figure b and Table S3 of the )]. This is in good agreement with the previously reported phenomenon. However, we could additionally observe that the linear relation between the Zn/C ratio and surface area is valid only in the case of MOFs with rigid ligands [i.e., benzene derivatives like 1,4-BDC, 1,3,5-BTC, and 2,6-NDC, whereas the MOFs containing flexible ligands like 1,3-ADA and 1,4-PAA result in low surface area carbons and henceforth fail to fall in the linear plot (Figure e)]. This may be due to the close resemblance in the property of alicyclic linkers of MOFs, particularly the adamantane-based ligand with the pitchlike compounds, which hints at the existence of a mesophase intermediate state prior to the solid "soft" carbon formation.

elements.content: The increments in the surface area of the carbon when compared to its parent MOF in the cases of C- MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC are nearly 22, 26, and 30 times higher, whereas for C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn-ADA this increase is only 13- to 15-fold. From the surface area studies, it is clear that the presence of these kinds of pure sp3 (Zn–ADA) or sp2 with some sp3 (Zn–PAA) hybrid carbons in the linker backbone of MOFs decreases the surface area of the resulting carbon to a large extent, when compared to the carbon synthesized using rigid linkers. This implies that the linear relationship between the surface area of carbon materials and the Zn/C ratio of MOF precursors is consistent only for the carbons resulting from the MOFs having rigid linkers (Figuree).
elements.clean_text: The increments in the surface area of the carbon when compared to its parent MOF in the cases of C- MOF-2, C-Zn-NDC, and C-Zn-BTC are nearly 22, 26, and 30 times higher, whereas for C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA this increase is only 13- to 15-fold. From the surface area studies, it is clear that the presence of these kinds of pure sp3 (Zn-ADA) or sp2 with some sp3 (Zn-PAA) hybrid carbons in the linker backbone of MOFs decreases the surface area of the resulting carbon to a large extent, when compared to the carbon synthesized using rigid linkers. This implies that the linear relationship between the surface area of carbon materials and the Zn/C ratio of MOF precursors is consistent only for the carbons resulting from the MOFs having rigid linkers (Figuree).

elements.content: Gas adsorption analyses of carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs. (a and b) represent N2 adsorption isotherms of carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and flexible linkers, respectively, after evacuation at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (c and d) represent H2 adsorption isotherms for carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and carbons derived from MOFs with flexible linkers, respectively, at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (e) Plot of surface area vs Zn/C ratio. (f) Plot of H2 uptake vs percentage microporosity. (The ● and ○ circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.)
elements.clean_text: 2  Gas adsorption analyses of carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs. (a and b) represent N2 adsorption isotherms of carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and flexible linkers, respectively, after evacuation at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (c and d) represent H2 adsorption isotherms for carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and carbons derived from MOFs with flexible linkers, respectively, at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (e) Plot of surface area vs Zn/C ratio. (f) Plot of H2 uptake vs percentage microporosity. (The ● and ○ circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.)

elements.content: The overall difference in the BET surface area and porosity in these resulting carbons prompted us to analyze the H2 and CO2 adsorption properties of the carbons. The H2 (77 K) and CO2 (273 K) adsorption isotherms show typical type I isotherms without hysteresis. As shown in Figure c, C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC show 260, 223, 209, and 184 cc/g of the H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm pressure. On the other hand, as pressure approaches 1 atm, C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA adsorbs 136 and 151 cc/g of H2 at the same conditions (Figured). The CO2 adsorption data collected for C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC show 107, 100, 80, and 88 cc/g of the CO2 at 273 K and 1 atm pressure. In the similar conditions, C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA adsorb 95 and 73 cc/g of the CO2 (Figure S15 of the ). The increase in the carbon microporosity results in higher H2 and CO2 uptake as the adsorption potential increases with increased number of adsorption sites and with better agreement between the pore size and kinetic diameter of the incoming gas molecules (Figure f and Figure S14 of the ).
elements.clean_text: The overall difference in the BET surface area and porosity in these resulting carbons prompted us to analyze the H2 and CO2 adsorption properties of the carbons. The H2 (77 K) and CO2 (273 K) adsorption isotherms show typical type I isotherms without hysteresis. As shown in Figure c, C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C-Zn-NDC, and C-Zn-BTC show 260, 223, 209, and 184 cc/g of the H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm pressure. On the other hand, as pressure approaches 1 atm, C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA adsorbs 136 and 151 cc/g of H2 at the same conditions (Figured). The CO2 adsorption data collected for C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C-Zn-NDC, and C-Zn-BTC show 107, 100, 80, and 88 cc/g of the CO2 at 273 K and 1 atm pressure. In the similar conditions, C-Zn-PAA and C-Zn-ADA adsorb 95 and 73 cc/g of the CO2 (Figure S15 of the ). The increase in the carbon microporosity results in higher H2 and CO2 uptake as the adsorption potential increases with increased number of adsorption sites and with better agreement between the pore size and kinetic diameter of the incoming gas molecules (Figure f and Figure S14 of the ).

elements.content: High surface area and presence of porosity in the carbon matrix encouraged us to test the potential of these materials for energy devices such as supercapacitors. In order to study the capacitive nature of the porous carbons, a symmetrical capacitor was constructed using each carbon sample (1 mg loading containing 85% of active material). The electrodes were then dipped in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte and the cyclic voltammetry and charge–discharge measurements were performed at a 10 mV/s scan rate and at different current densities (0.5 to 10 mA/cm2) in the potential range of 0–1.0 V. From Figure b, the specific capacitance of C-MOF-2, C-MOF-5, C–Zn–BTC, C–Zn–NDC, C–Zn–PAA, and C–Zn–ADA is calculated as 170, 150, 134, 114, 110, and 95 F/g, respectively, at a current density of 1 A/g. Figure c gives the retention plot of capacitance with current density from 1 to 10 A/g. The carbons from rigid linkers (i.e., C-MOF-5,C-MOF-2, C–Zn–BTC, and C–Zn–NDC show retention ability of 79, 81, 84, and 80%, respectively, while C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA show 74 and 63% capacitance retention, respectively). From the electrochemical tests, it can be observed that carbons show increased capacitance with increasing surface area (Figure d). This is in agreement with the known surface area–capacitance dependence, wherein, in case of porous carbons devoid of any metal/metal oxide impurities, the capacity of the carbon to store charges and form a double layer increases with porosity and surface area. Of all carbons, the better retention ability of carbons derived from MOF with rigid linkers, in particular C-MOF-2, can mainly be credited to their relatively higher mesoporous content (as calculated from the pore size distribution plot, Figures S11 and S12 and Table S3 of the ), which thereby results in larger pores that allow better and faster diffusion of ions during rapid cycling at higher current density. The carbons derived from flexible linkers (i.e., C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA) show lower retention of 74 and 63%, respectively, possibly due to the presence of smaller pores in the carbon structure, as reflected from the TEM analyses. Of all, the highest retention capacity of C–Zn–BTC (84%) can be attributed to the large percent of mesopore content (from the pore size distribution plot) along with the presence of sulfur (as evident from EDAX, Figure S10 of the ), wherein the mesopores allow easy diffusion of counterions and heteroatoms like sulfur are reported to improve the wettability of the electrode surface as well as impart pseudocapacitance.Although MOF-derived carbons have been previously investigated as potential electrodic materials, little has been studied on the relevance of the pore structure and surface area to the capacitance. In the present work, C-MOF-2 shows highest capacitance of 170 F/g at 1 A/g current density [165 F/g at 10 mV/s] with a BET surface area of 1378 m2/g (Table S2 of the ). It is important to note the absence of any heteroatoms in the C-MOF-2 basic structure, wherein the capacitance is mainly credited to the charge stored at the electrode–electrolyte interface, unlike in cases of N-doped carbons where the pseudo capacitance adds largely to the basic inherent capacitance of the material.

In the present work, C-MOF-2 shows highest capacitance of 170 F/g at 1 A/g current density [165 F/g at 10 mV/s] with a BET surface area of 1378 m2/g (Table S2 of the ). It is important to note the absence of any heteroatoms in the C-MOF-2 basic structure, wherein the capacitance is mainly credited to the charge stored at the electrode-electrolyte interface, unlike in cases of N-doped carbons where the pseudo capacitance adds largely to the basic inherent capacitance of the material.

(d) Plot of variation of capacitance versus surface area.

elements.content: In the present work, nanoporous carbons were obtained on direct carbonization of nonporous Zn-based MOFs and the impact of the flexibility of constituting MOF ligands on the properties of the resulting carbons were studied. The MOFs with rigid benzene-based ligands are observed to result in high surface area carbons with good H2 and CO2 uptake and demonstrate good potential as a capacitive electrode unlike those achieved using flexible ligands. This pathway opens up the way for the usage of nonporous MOFs toward the synthesis of highly porous carbons, which may pave the way for future applications like gas storage and gas separation apart from the devices like supercapacitors and batteries.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, nanoporous carbons were obtained on direct carbonization of nonporous Zn-based MOFs and the impact of the flexibility of constituting MOF ligands on the properties of the resulting carbons were studied. The MOFs with rigid benzene-based ligands are observed to result in high surface area carbons with good H2 and CO2 uptake and demonstrate good potential as a capacitive electrode unlike those achieved using flexible ligands. This pathway opens up the way for the usage of nonporous MOFs toward the synthesis of highly porous carbons, which may pave the way for future applications like gas storage and gas separation apart from the devices like supercapacitors and batteries.

elements.content: Description of experimental details of MOFs, including their synthetic methods and supplementary figures, including TGA, powder XRD profiles for MOFs and carbons, SEM images, EDAX reports, TEM images, gas adsorption study, and crystallographic information for MOF. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Physical/Materials Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune 411008, India.

References

Zn-based MOFs used in this study were synthesized by following literature procedures, except with Zn-ADA MOF.

Physical/Materials Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune 411008, India.

References

Zn-based MOFs used in this study were synthesized by following literature procedures, except with Zn-ADA MOF.

cln_elements.content:
The N2 adsorption analyses of the activated samples of MOFs indicate that except MOF-5 [Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, 2385 m2/g], all other MOFs have poor/no porosity with surface area between 20–65 m2/g (Figure S8 of the ). The gas adsorption analyses of MOF-derived carbons show typical Type-I N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms without any hysteresis, which suggests a dominating microporous nature in the carbon matrix (Figure ). The BET surface areas calculated between a pressure range of 0.1–0.3 atm for carbons derived from MOFs having rigid aromatic linkers [i.e., C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–BTC, and C–Zn–NDC are 2184, 1378, 1326, and 920 m2/g respectively (Figure a)]. However, the BET surface areas of carbons synthesized from the MOFs with flexible linkers [i.e., C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn-ADA are 495 and 513 m2/g, respectively (Figure b and Table S3 of the )]. This is in good agreement with the previously reported phenomenon. However, we could additionally observe that the linear relation between the Zn/C ratio and surface area is valid only in the case of MOFs with rigid ligands [i.e., benzene derivatives like 1,4-BDC, 1,3,5-BTC, and 2,6-NDC, whereas the MOFs containing flexible ligands like 1,3-ADA and 1,4-PAA result in low surface area carbons and henceforth fail to fall in the linear plot (Figure e)]. This may be due to the close resemblance in the property of alicyclic linkers of MOFs, particularly the adamantane-based ligand with the pitchlike compounds, which hints at the existence of a mesophase intermediate state prior to the solid “soft” carbon formation.

The overall difference in the BET surface area and porosity in these resulting carbons prompted us to analyze the H2 and CO2 adsorption properties of the carbons. The H2 (77 K) and CO2 (273 K) adsorption isotherms show typical type I isotherms without hysteresis. As shown in Figure c, C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC show 260, 223, 209, and 184 cc/g of the H2 uptake at 77 K and 1 atm pressure. On the other hand, as pressure approaches 1 atm, C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA adsorbs 136 and 151 cc/g of H2 at the same conditions (Figured). The CO2 adsorption data collected for C-MOF-5, C-MOF-2, C–Zn–NDC, and C–Zn–BTC show 107, 100, 80, and 88 cc/g of the CO2 at 273 K and 1 atm pressure. In the similar conditions, C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA adsorb 95 and 73 cc/g of the CO2 (Figure S15 of the ). The increase in the carbon microporosity results in higher H2 and CO2 uptake as the adsorption potential increases with increased number of adsorption sites and with better agreement between the pore size and kinetic diameter of the incoming gas molecules (Figure f and Figure S14 of the ).

High surface area and presence of porosity in the carbon matrix encouraged us to test the potential of these materials for energy devices such as supercapacitors. In order to study the capacitive nature of the porous carbons, a symmetrical capacitor was constructed using each carbon sample (1 mg loading containing 85% of active material). The electrodes were then dipped in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte and the cyclic voltammetry and charge–discharge measurements were performed at a 10 mV/s scan rate and at different current densities (0.5 to 10 mA/cm2) in the potential range of 0–1.0 V. From Figure b, the specific capacitance of C-MOF-2, C-MOF-5, C–Zn–BTC, C–Zn–NDC, C–Zn–PAA, and C–Zn–ADA is calculated as 170, 150, 134, 114, 110, and 95 F/g, respectively, at a current density of 1 A/g. Figure c gives the retention plot of capacitance with current density from 1 to 10 A/g. The carbons from rigid linkers (i.e., C-MOF-5,C-MOF-2, C–Zn–BTC, and C–Zn–NDC show retention ability of 79, 81, 84, and 80%, respectively, while C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA show 74 and 63% capacitance retention, respectively). From the electrochemical tests, it can be observed that carbons show increased capacitance with increasing surface area (Figure d). This is in agreement with the known surface area–capacitance dependence, wherein, in case of porous carbons devoid of any metal/metal oxide impurities, the capacity of the carbon to store charges and form a double layer increases with porosity and surface area. Of all carbons, the better retention ability of carbons derived from MOF with rigid linkers, in particular C-MOF-2, can mainly be credited to their relatively higher mesoporous content (as calculated from the pore size distribution plot, Figures S11 and S12 and Table S3 of the ), which thereby results in larger pores that allow better and faster diffusion of ions during rapid cycling at higher current density. The carbons derived from flexible linkers (i.e., C–Zn–PAA and C–Zn–ADA) show lower retention of 74 and 63%, respectively, possibly due to the presence of smaller pores in the carbon structure, as reflected from the TEM analyses. Of all, the highest retention capacity of C–Zn–BTC (84%) can be attributed to the large percent of mesopore content (from the pore size distribution plot) along with the presence of sulfur (as evident from EDAX, Figure S10 of the ), wherein the mesopores allow easy diffusion of counterions and heteroatoms like sulfur are reported to improve the wettability of the electrode surface as well as impart pseudocapacitance.Although MOF-derived carbons have been previously investigated as potential electrodic materials, little has been studied on the relevance of the pore structure and surface area to the capacitance. In the present work, C-MOF-2 shows highest capacitance of 170 F/g at 1 A/g current density [165 F/g at 10 mV/s] with a BET surface area of 1378 m2/g (Table S2 of the ). It is important to note the absence of any heteroatoms in the C-MOF-2 basic structure, wherein the capacitance is mainly credited to the charge stored at the electrode–electrolyte interface, unlike in cases of N-doped carbons where the pseudo capacitance adds largely to the basic inherent capacitance of the material.

cln_elements.content:
Schematic Representation for the Synthesis of Porous Carbon on Direct Carbonization of (a) Porous MOF and (b) Nonporous MOFs at 1000 °C Along with their N<sub>2</sub> Adsorption Isotherms<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The structures of the nonporous MOFs, MOF-2, Zn–NDC, Zn–BTC, and Zn–PAA are shown inside the green frame. Solvent molecules present in the MOF structures are omitted for clarity. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, grey.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation for the Synthesis of Porous Carbon on Direct Carbonization of (a) Porous MOF and (b) Nonporous MOFs at 1000 °C Along with their N2 Adsorption Isotherms      a The structures of the nonporous MOFs, MOF-2, Zn-NDC, Zn-BTC, and Zn-PAA are shown inside the green frame. Solvent molecules present in the MOF structures are omitted for clarity. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, grey.

cln_elements.content: Secondary Binding Units (SBUs) of MOFs and corresponding SEM and TEM images of porous carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs at 1000 °C. The ranking of the constituting rigid/flexible ligands is made based on the number of sp2/sp3 carbons present in their backbone.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Secondary Binding Units (SBUs) of MOFs and corresponding SEM and TEM images of porous carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs at 1000 °C. The ranking of the constituting rigid/flexible ligands is made based on the number of sp2/sp3 carbons present in their backbone.

cln_elements.content: Gas adsorption analyses of carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs. (a and b) represent N2 adsorption isotherms of carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and flexible linkers, respectively, after evacuation at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (c and d) represent H2 adsorption isotherms for carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and carbons derived from MOFs with flexible linkers, respectively, at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (e) Plot of surface area vs Zn/C ratio. (f) Plot of H2 uptake vs percentage microporosity. (The ● and ○ circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Gas adsorption analyses of carbons obtained on direct carbonization of MOFs. (a and b) represent N2 adsorption isotherms of carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and flexible linkers, respectively, after evacuation at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (c and d) represent H2 adsorption isotherms for carbons derived from MOFs with rigid linkers and carbons derived from MOFs with flexible linkers, respectively, at 77 K and 1 bar pressure. (e) Plot of surface area vs Zn/C ratio. (f) Plot of H2 uptake vs percentage microporosity. (The ● and ○ circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.)

metadata.title:
Porous Carbons from Nonporous MOFs: Influence of Ligand
Characteristics on Intrinsic Properties of End Carbon
